newsitem.title: QATAR: Qatar advises citizens to be cautious in Bahrain.
newsitem.headline: Qatar advises citizens to be cautious in Bahrain.

text.p: Qatar on Wednesday advised its citizens to exercise caution when travelling to its Gulf Arab neighbour Bahrain following the arrest there of two Qataris on spy charges.
The Qatari cabinet said in a statement after its weekly meeting that it had discussed the arrest of the two Qataris in Bahrain "and the inhuman treatment they are receiving".

"...The cabinet urges all Qatari citizens to exercise caution when they have to visit Bahrain for fear that what the Bahraini authorities did will reoccur to other (Qatari) citizens," the statement carried by the official Qatar News Agency said.
Bahrain last month arrested the two, Fahad Hamad Abdullah al-Baker and Salwa Jassim Mohammed Fakhri, on charges of spying for Qatar. The two countries are locked in a border dispute.
Qatar denied the two were spies, said the charges were fabricated and accused Bahrain of torturing al-Baker. Bahrain denied the charge and said the two were being well-treated.
Bahrain's State Security Court -- whose sentences cannot be appealed -- adjourned their trial to December 14. If found guilty they could be executed or face long prison terms.

The cabinet statement said the Emir Sheikh Hamad bin Khalifa al-Thani had issued instructions that Bahrainis in Qatar should be well-treated and that their wellbeing should not be affected by the arrest of the two Qataris in Bahrain.
The arrest has raised tensions between the two Gulf Arab states, which are in dispute over small islands in the Gulf controlled by Bahrain since the 1930s.
Bahrain cited the dispute as the reason it boycotted a Gulf Arab summit which ended in Qatar on Monday. The summit agreed to form a three-nation committee to try to resolve the row.
